this course focuses on theories and approaches in second language acquisition that inform language teaching in the classroom the students will explore how first and second languages are acquired during childhood adolescence and adulthood focusing on the factors that influence their development such as individual differences as well as the discussion of key concepts such as interlanguage error correction bilingualism and the role of cognition and social interaction general to demonstrate understanding of the fundamental processes involved in the acquisition of language to analyze different theories of language acquisition to reflect critically on the different aspects that affect second language acquisition specific to identify the developmental processes involved in childhood and adolescence that are interrelated in the process of language acquisition to develop critical approach to how languages are learned during childhood adolescence and adulthood to analyze different learning strategies and evaluate their presence children adolescents or adults to analyze types of errors in language and possible causes of the errors based on theories the student masters the theoretical and practical course aiming to develop oral proficiency in the production of english speech it will focus on articulatory phonetics and the classification of sounds in english it will explain how english is pronounced in the context of general theory about speech sounds and how they are organized in the english language this course is tackled through practical procedural and implementation issues related to pronunciation teaching teaching approaches and classroom applied phonetics is designed to allow students to explore these areas as the basis for applied phonetics to describe how speech sounds are produced to describe sound production with reference to the articulatory track to link perceptual descriptions with production and explain in general how perceptually different sounds differ in their production to distinguish the classification of speech sounds and discuss their phonological groupings and distributions in english to identify and understand the nature of the syllabic structure of english to analyze different proposals for pronunciation teaching in to apply the knowledge of the english phonological system to effective teaching practices the student masters the english language at an advanced level and is able to communicate fluently and precisely in order to provide learning opportunities for the integrated development of communicative skills in english domina lengua inglesa nivel avanzado comunica forma precisa fluida ofrecer oportunidades aprendizaje orientadas desarrollo integrado habilidades comunicativas ingles subcompetencias the articulatory production of speech sounds voice production and the organs of speech the larynx its structure and the role it plays in speech production consonantal elements in speech english consonants their production perceptual qualities place and manner of articulation of the phonemic status of some consonants the production of vocalic elements in speech cardinal vowels and their representation english vowels their production perceptual qualities and representation long short vowels diphthongs and tripthongs the syllable the nature of the syllable the structure of the syllable consonant clusters phonology and pronunciation learning and teaching the nature of phonology and phonetics phonology in language learning and teaching learner and teacher pronunciation competence the purpose of this course is to explore basic theories of linguistics and their application to classroom practice emphasizing how the knowledge of the way languages work will directly benefit the teaching of english language learners the course provides an overview of linguistic sociolinguistic and psycholinguistic analyses that inform decisions in the classroom in the areas of language acquisition language comprehension and production and language planning among others to demonstrate understanding of the value of linguistic knowledge when applied to the study of language and this course will cover some of the key works of fiction films and other cultural productions of american western literature from the beginning of the through to today novels by james fenimore cooper owen wister and willar cather will form the core of our reading while we will also watch and consider some of the western most significant cinematic productions and think about some central western essays memoires illustrations and paintings these texts will be contextualised with an understanding of the development of conceptions of the frontier from the war of independence through manifest destiny the gilded age and new imperial period to the the cold war and growing understanding of the destruction caused by the mishandling of its frontier the central writers of american western literature and their key works the political and cultural history of the wild west the cultural political and literary origins of the figure of the cowboy firm understanding of the frontier and more general ideas about frontier literature the variety of voices that lie beneath the apparently white mythological surface of the wild west the themes and tropes of american western literature and filmmaking new understandings of the complex interrelated geographical and sociological spaces of the west and queer theories in application to the american west critical evaluative and presentation skills byronic frontiersman will look at the century origins of some western tropes fenimore the last of the mohicans american romantic inheritance of the west paintings of frederic remington viewed alongside the fiction and criticism of owen wister and the memoirs of theodore roosevelt the virginian the west pioneers wests westerns and the recreation of the west proulx and discussion of texts and discussion of films learning tasks and projects presentations paper presentation test research project on recent western films set texts john cawelti the mystique frederick jackson turner significance of the frontier in american james fenimore cooper the last of the mohicans owen wister the virginian willa cather pioneers annie proulx close range wyoming stories suggested further this course seminar aims at providing different theoretical approaches and tools for the study and analysis of translation literary linguistic discoursal and applied linguistic problem areas worth exploring and doing applied research on the review of the most recently published literature in these areas will make the student aware of the nature of the problems in each field and will disclose in possibilities of applied research according to interests generals to acquire general view of the most recently published literature in each english language discipline to evaluate the reviewed literature and discover relevant problem areas to plan applied research according to interests specifics to do bibliographical research in an english language discipline to acquire and evaluate different theoretical approaches in each discipline for better understanding of relevant problem areas to identify possible areas of research according to interests to gather corpora for the analysis of identified problems worth doing research on to select theoretical approach and apply it to the analysis and interpretation of relevant problem identified in the corpus to produce written research paper containing the theoretical framework used the analysis and interpretation of the analyzed data and projections in the field of knowledge the contents will correspond to the topic chosen as the object of study group work discussions opinions and contributions individual work oral presentation for the class one grade for regular progress reports and the resarch project at the end of the semester one grade for an oral group report the bibliography will be established in each case according to the selected discipline of the seminar and according to research interest in the field julio

the focus of this course will be the analysis and discussion of short stories representative of the literature of english speaking countries the approach to the texts will consider literary theory literary criticism and personal interpretation generals to become acquainted with the short fiction of important writers of the english speaking world to become acquainted with short story literary theory specifics to analyze and discuss selection of short stories of english speaking countries to understand the evolution of the short story and its different trends identify and analyze the points the sequence of the english language courses in the first four semesters of the licenciatura letras inglesas attempts to develop the four skills pertaining to the learning of foreign language in progressive levels of proficiency english language reaches an advanced level general to achieve linguistic competence in the management of and issues at an advanced level of proficiency specific to improve reading skills and strategies through the exposure to variety of text types and genres in authentic reading passages to understand wide range of demanding longer texts and recognize implicit meaning to interact in communicative oral situations fluently and spontaneously without much obvious searching for expressions to produce narrative descriptive and argumentative written texts in the sequence of the english language courses in the first four semesters of the licenciatura letras inglesas attempts to develop the four skills pertaining to the learning of foreign language in progressive levels of proficiency general to develop the language skills and competencies necessary to interact effectively in range of situations at an advanced level of proficiency specific to listen comprehensively to variety of authentic texts to apply listening strategies to the further development of speaking skills to interact in range of everyday situations using appropriate structure and vocabulary to read comprehensively texts of different lengths and with an increasing degree of complexity comparing evaluating and synthesizing their contents to read literary and historical texts critically and regard them in the light of their historical moments to produce critical argumentative texts regarding the reading seen in class to increase lexical availability to develop awareness of cultural issues and develop critical thinking to listen to and read variety of authentic texts with the purpose of getting used to answering different exam questions and improving their receptive skills to interact in and listening and reading activities using appropriate structure and vocabulary to produce written texts of different nature and length using appropriate format and structures lexical contents vocabulary related to talking about language learning and classes vocabulary related to job description vocabulary related to description of places vocabulary related to aspects of law vocabulary related to food preparation idioms related to work vocabulary related to disasters and natural phenomena vocabulary related to parts of the body and collocations used in physical descriptions vocabulary related to health and vocabulary related to politics and elections vocabulary related to weather and weather problems vocabulary related to challenging activities and changes vocabulary related to personal qualities and skills idioms related to relationships words related to the quality of life grammatical contents modifying nouns and adjectives comparison of adjectives does not apply curriculum minimum thesis alphanumerical the student will prepare an oral presentation of the progress made during the first year of the research semester to the thesis committee likewise and if necessary propose any necessary modifications to the research process for the future this academic activity requires completing the previous requirements of the curriculum and those established in the program regulations the main objective of this activity is to assess the degree of progress of the thesis project to identify the difficulties and to guide the student in the case that change of objectives is required present the achievements during the planned research activities discuss the proposed modifications to the doctoral research elaboration of progress report of the thesis project considering the obtained results difficulties changes of objectives generation of products presentations to congress publications preparation of progress report of the thesis formal oral presentation of research achievements during the first year of development before the thesis committee the student will prepare progress report in which demonstrates the degree of fulfillment of the objectives committed for the period justifies the and proposes strategies to continue with the development of the project this activity will be evaluated as distinguished approved or failed by the thesis commission considering the written report and the oral presentation required the literature will be defined in accordance with the topics studied complementary the literature will be defined in accordance with the topics studied

does not apply curriculum minimum thesis standard the doctoral thesis consists of an original and independent scientific investigation that constitutes in the opinion of the thesis commission significant contribution to the discipline in the interface of engineering biology and medicine the thesis is formal document whose purpose is to show the contribution made failure to show this contribution implies failing to defend the proposed thesis in doctoral thesis the student will continue the reseach activites started in doctoral thesis and according to the work plan approved in the thesis project and will made modifications to this work plan if needed continue the implementation of the working plan continue data processing to give answers to research questions reflect and discuss about the difficulties encountered in the ongoing investigation process propose the modifications that must be made to the process of investigation in course elaborate manuscript containing the most relevant findings submit research paper to an indexed scientific journal defined by the student under the supervision of his thesis director they must be approved by the thesis committee in the annual thesis monitoring activity indivual supervision sessions with the thesis supervisor individual work at the end of the semester the student needs to write final report containing the progress achieved during the semester it is recommended that the student works on his report throughout the semester the report is reviewed and evaluated by the thesis supervisor scale from to required the literature will be defined in accordance with the topics studied complementary the literature will be defined in accordance with the topics studied

none curriculum minimum thesis standard develop research project in the interface of engineering biology and medicine this research unit must be supervised by an academic and involves load of credits experiments fieldwork literature review the goal is to follow and develop specific work plan to prepare the thesis project based on the research question identified in the interdisciplinary research unit the research unit includes thesis project and at the end of the semester students must present the project orally in seminar general design thesis project that should include project formulation literature discussion hypothesis goals methodology work plan and expected outcomes specific formulate project review relevant literature define the hypothesis of the research project stablish research goals design work plan define expected outcomes of the doctoral thesis defined by the supervising professor indivual supervision sessions with the thesis supervisor individual work the evaluation of the research unit should comply with the following criteria student evaluation in the laboratory field office written thesis project oral presentation of the thesis project required the literature will be defined in accordance with the topics studied complementary the literature will be defined in accordance with the topics studied

requisitos postgraduate level curriculum minimum workshop standard academicos engineering biology and medicine this course provides forum for postgraduate students of the institute for biological and medical engineering they can participate in presentations by researchers teachers and other peers in such way to instill culture of discussion and critical thinking from the scientific point of view series of seminars will be held which will include the presentation of students faculty and special guests the purpose of this course is to raise awareness about contingent problems and how science related to the interface of biology medicine and engineering can address them moreover this course will provide students with the tools to write scientific summaries with clear organized and motivating structure as well as tools for creating clear and consistent oral presentations taking into account structure organization and content general the capacity of scientific criticism and to propose and defend relevant research topics and train specialists with skills in critical synthetic and purposeful analysis capable of developing research and innovation in their field and level of competence specific appraise published literature in the interface of engineering biology and medicine the latest advances in scientific scholarship and the needs of the community in relevant research areas related to engineering biology and medicine the above appraisals effectively in the form of oral presentations and written review published work and present findings in written report and oral presentation aspects related to the interface of engineering biology and medicine and current problems awareness of important topics in the interface of engineering biology and medicine oral and written communication skills scientific summaries with clear organized and motivating structure clear and consistent oral presentations taking into account structure organization and content scientific discussion and critical thinking theme of the presentations will be delivered in timely manner for each of these presentations the student should come prepared to discuss the work during the respective presentation elements for the presentation of works in front of the professors of bibliographical work or advance of thesis previously assigned at the beginning of the semester of invited professors of professors of the institute for biological and medical engineering the course there will be workshops how to write scientific summaries what it is and how to do an elevator pitch how to prepare oral presentations intellectual property and patenting studies and presentations of application project s of seminars abstracts of your abstracts presentation of your own and peer presentations presentation pitch participation scientific discussion and critical analysis required the craft of scientific presentations critical steps to succeed and critical errors to avoid springer new york trees maps and theorems effective communication for rational minds principiæ kraainem intellectual property handbook policy law and use http material handed out in class complementary literature will be defined in accordance with the topics

requisitos postgraduate level curriculum minimum workshop standard academicos engineering biology and medicine the course aims to provide students with project management techniques and interdisciplinary skills that are directly applicable to their future research projects students will work in teams to engage in practical project requiring input from variety of scientific areas related to the interface of engineering biology and medicine project questions will be defined by the group of participating professors who will also be responsible for the direct supervision of the research work together with external company advisors at least two professors from different field supervise each group students are expected to gain some experience in the various different aspects of group collaboration these include running meetings making collective decisions time and people management and writing reports students must combine skills related to the identification and resolution of biomedical problems through collaborative design innovation use of information technologies computational modeling medical ethics and social responsibility general students to manage and operate in an interdisciplinary group project specific realistic experimental project in which they can work in team to apply both technical and interpersonal management skills develop appropriate experimental processes and techniques for their defined aims basic project planning including assessment of risks and challenges within defined timescale investigations and appraise progress through communication within an interdisciplinary scientific team the importance of the skills in interdisciplinary projects experimental or technical skills may also be acquired as result of the various aspects of the group project understanding of requirements and definition of tasks study analysis and study design experimental work of the various project components interpretation and communication of results project planning and management research study design interdisciplinary teamwork and communication skills development of multidisciplinary scientific communication studies and presentations of application project project written report project oral presentation assessment presentation interview and project report even if most of the work of this course will be done in teams all evaluations will assess both the group and the individual students required richards interdisciplinary discourse communicating across disciplines london palgrave macmillan complementary perspectives in translational research in life sciences and biomedicine translational outcomes research in life sciences and translational medicine volume singapore springer

curriculum minimum lecture standard engineering biology and medicine the aim of this course is to teach students the mathematical concepts and computational tools that are commonly used in modeling and simulating physical biological and medical phenomena the course will focus on using numerical simulations and experiments to illustrate teh application of teh mathematical concepts being presented intuition algorithms and computational issues will be emphasized over abstract results the main objective of teh course is for students to learn the essential mathematical and computational tools needed to undertake research in biological and medical engineering and to be able to develop new mathematical models or computational methods tailored to their specific research areas in biological and medical engineering identify the elementary mathematical models underlying some common biological or medical phenomena implement teh essential numerical methods required to perform numerical simulation of an elementary mathematical model of biological or medical phenomena evaluate the benefits and drawbacks of mathematical models of biological or medical phenomena through numerical simulations propose new mathematical models or modifications of common mathematical models for biological or medical phenomena introduction to scientific computing introduction to the python language for scientific computing elements of scientific computing elements of numerical linear algebra ordinary differential equations odes biological and medical phenomena and the intuition behind an definition geometric intuition existence and uniqueness of solutions equilibria and stability linear systems of odes numerical solution to odes applied harmonic analysis the importance of acquiring biological and medical signals linear time invariant systems as modeling tool action of an system on complex exponentials and the fourier transform the transfer function of an system harmonic analysis and synthesis the discrete fourier transform and the fast fourier transform sampling of signals bandlimited signals and the theorem elements of time series analysis optimization biological and medical phenomena as an process unconstrained optimization necessary and sufficient conditions and and optimality conditions elements of line search and algorithms linearly constrained problems necessary and sufficient conditions and the conditions elements of constrained optimization and numerical solvers probabilistic models the random nature of some biological and medical phenomena elements of probability theory probability measure random variables and probability distributions expectation and variance statistical independence covariance and correlation and conditional expectation the law of large numbers and the central limit theorem random walks markov chains renewal processes lectures computational workshops homework project mandatory ascher greif first course in numerical methods society for applied and computational mathematics complementary durret probability theory and examples edition cambridge university press cambridge holmes introduction to scientific computing and data analysis springer international publishing switzerland ingalls mathematical modelling in systems biology an introduction press strang computational science and engineering press tveito et elements of scientific computing berlin

curriculum minimum lecture standard engineering biology and medicine this course provides general view of regenerative medicine and tissue engineering including topics such as biocompatibility vascularization degradable scaffolds cell therapies cellularized scaffolds and the use of biological and chemical factors to improve tissue repair and regeneration moreover it will cover wide selection of mathematical models in physiology and biomechanics showing how physiological problems can be formulated and studied mathematically and how such models give rise to interesting and challenging mathematical questions at the same time the course shows how biomechanical principals are applied to the modeling of biological tissue explain and apply basic concepts of tissue regeneration biomechanics and mathematical modeling of physiological systems compare different alternatives to improve tissue regeneration using artificial scaffolds and factors develop and build engineering models dat describe physiological systems such as the cardiovascular and the respiratory system analyze scientific literature on tissue engineering regenerative medicine biomechanics and quantitative physiology communicate scientific information both by written documents and oral presentations to specific audiences introduction to tissue engineering and regeneration history of tissue engineering biomimetic approaches cell tissue and organ development interactions in vitro control of tissue regeneration tissue development in vitro use of degradable scaffolds interactions biocompatibility and cytotoxicity immunomodulation vascularization stem cells in vivo tissue engineering case studies tissue engineering of skin muscle bone etc animal and clinical studies regulatory considerations introduction to biomechanics and quantitative physiology controlling mechanisms in human body balance laws and biophysical principals mathematical models of physiological systems electrical conduction system of the heart hemodynamics and the cardiovascular system respiratory system muscle skeletal system nervous system lectures and case studies assignments development and presentations of application project s quizzes assignments and reports final written report oral defense of the applied project minima humphrey an introduction to biomechanics solids and fluids analysis and design edition springer new york keener sneyd mathematical physiology springer new york lanza langer vacanti principals of tissue engineering edition elsevier amsterdam ratner hoffman schoen lemons biomaterials science an introduction to materials in medicine edition elsevier london complementary the literature will be defined in accordance with the topics studied

this course promotes appreciation of literature as an artistic cultural and educational manifestation which is fundamental for child development it provides the prospective teacher with an understanding of literature written by english speaking communities and in various multicultural settings that allows them to select analyze interpret and produce literary and works in print or digital environments meant to be read and listened to by students at this level the course explores the subgenres within literature fairy tales folk tales fables poems and picture books among others from pedagogical perspective to recognize and compare variety of literary genres for children and their specific characteristics in order to discern which genres would be suitable for specific learning community of learners with specific likes and needs in given context and time to critically analyze wide range of literary texts for children printed and in digital environments in order to develop critical competencies that enable the to assess any literary text and its potential to assess the specific contribution of diverse texts for children to the english teaching and learning process the student masters the english language at an advanced level and is able to communicate fluently and precisely in order to offer provide learning opportunities for the integrated development this course attempts to consolidate communicative competence in english at an advanced level acquired in previous courses it provides opportunities for the reconceptualization of their knowledge of english understood as the specific language skills teachers need for teaching additionally the course focuses on developing linguistic and cultural awareness of spanish speaking communities so as to establish comparisons with the target language to be used in the classroom promoting intercultural communication to adapt their linguistic resources to the educational context by using appropriate pedagogical discourse for modeling instruction and effective communication in the classroom based on student level to integrate oral and written communicative competencies in school context by both describing how the english language works at its various levels and employing that knowledge in oral and written tasks to develop linguistic and cultural awareness of spanish speaking communities so as to establish comparisons with the target language to be used in the classroom to value own culture and promote intercultural communication for effective classroom interaction by using different media the student masters the english language at an advanced level and is able to communicate fluently and precisely in order to provide learning opportunities for the integrated development of communication norms for communicating and collaborating in communities cultural views that affect what is considered appropriate in communities expressions of in communities lessons are designed to be include class discussion of readings and contents presentations and students apply and analyse contents in order to open up discussion with the whole class who in turn provide feedback group this course introduces student teachers to the profession of teaching english as foreign language as starting point for the building of professional identity it focuses on the central aspects of linguistic and communicative elements of english as well as the process with an emphasis on the understanding of the roles of the teacher and the learner student teachers will explore the role of english as an international language in chile and the diverse educational contexts in which english is taught and learned today including technology mediated learning to identify the linguistic and communicative elements of english needed for the teaching of the language in range of educational settings to reflect on the roles teachers and learners perform in the context of teaching english as foreign language for the progressive building of professional identity to demonstrate understanding of the different terminology used in the field of for the establishment of professional and academic links to national and international contexts to explain key issues about the global role of english within the digital context for the interaction with national and international contexts the student understands the structure and functioning of the english language and its cultural expressions in order to contextualize the developmental process of english communicative skills in the school context comprende estructura funcionamiento lengua inglesa manifestaciones culturales asociadas contextualizar proceso desarrollo habilidades comunicativas ingles contexto escolar subcompetencia perfil egreso pedagogia ingles educacion basica media the student researches reflects and provides arguments about own pedagogical practice and to improve the learning processes indaga reflexiona argumenta propia practica pedagogica mejorar procesos aprendizaje estudiantes subcompetencia perfil egreso pedagogia ingles educacion basica media the student is able to communicate appropriately and efficiently both in oral and written form in their relationship with the students and other members of the educational community so as to develop their teaching practice appropriately comunica adecuada eficazmente manera oral escrita relacion alumnos agentes comunidad educativa desarrollar adecuadamente labor docente subcompetencia perfil egreso pedagogia ingles educacion basica media the english language main characteristics the language system lexicogrammatical phonological pragmatic and discourse levels communicative skills listening speaking reading and writing areas of study within english linguistics and literature the learning and teaching of english contexts in which english is learned and taught english as foreign language english as second language english as an additional language english for specific purposes english for academic purposes primary and secondary education roles roles being an english teacher in the chilean context the field of english language teaching terminology in national and international professional contexts and associations english in the global world english as an international language learning and teaching english and in digital environments the methodology of the course consists of guided reading for the analysis and productive discussion of articles about the english language its components terminology and teaching implications in different contexts likewise for the representation of teaching practices application workshops will take place to reflect on teaching performances through the viewing of classroom patterns on video finally the student teacher the opportunity to approach the learning and teaching of english using digital tools to foster interaction among peers and small groups objective is assessed by means of periodical written quizzes in which the student teacher will explain the foundations of the english language and implications in addition the teacher will take part in an oral presentation expected to generate productive discussion for the critical analysis of the documents to address objective the student teacher will engage in periodical application workshops that go from the narrative of learning experience to the reflection of theoretical models and teaching practices for objective the student teacher will demonstrate understanding and apply concepts and terminology used in in different contexts through written test finally for objective the student teacher will have an oral presentation about in digital environments compulsory harmer essential teacher knowledge core concepts in this course aims at developing the knowledge and practical skills which are required to teach english to young learners effectively it provides practical ideas on how to approach and plan for young learners as well as materials and ideas for specific activities through the development of games songs and visual materials and their use in teaching and assessment of young english learners there is special focus on the development of literacy skills to grades together with the implementation of organizational routines procedures and strategies to support learning environment design and implement activities and teaching sequences for the development of written and integrated skills for young learners focusing on organizational routines in the classroom design and implement thematic units that incorporate topics from other disciplines for the teaching of english in an integrated fashion select and adapt tasks resources and assessment situations in various forms including digital environments for assess and provide effective feedback to young learners based on the analysis and interpretation of results to improve the learning student masters the english language at an advanced level and is able to communicate fluently and precisely in order to provide learning opportunities for the integrated development of communicative skills in english competencia sub competencia perfil egreso pedagogia ingles ed basica media student understands the structure and functioning of the english language and its cultural expressions in order to contextualize the developmental process of english communicative skills in the school context competencia sub competencias perfil egreso pedagogia ingles ed basica media student contextualizes the current curriculum for the planning of learning and assessment situations in primary and secondary education competencia subcompetencia perfil egreso pedagogia ingles ed basica media student makes pedagogical decisions considering biological psychological and sociocultural characteristics of primary and secondary school students and how they learn and develop in order to promote inclusive learning competnecia subcompetencia perfil egreso pedagogia ingles ed basica media student designs and implements teaching strategies for primary and secondary school coherent with learning goals consistent with disciplinary knowledge temas comportamiento administracion trimestral none elective lecture standard grades to this course explores the behavioral side of management issues building on the literature joining economics and management with psychology the course some of the assumptions we use to describe the behavior of managers and consumers to evidence that our decisions are not always rational understand behavioral issues in management give examples of basic concepts principles and values that constitute behavioral issues analyze how firms and markets react to behavioural issues describe situations where biases affect as individuals consumers workers and managers explore and evaluate cases from diverse fields of management such as organizational behavior human resources strategy pricing and finance definition of rationality hyperbolic discounting the observation that consumers have bias for present relative to future gratification preferences social preferences in general and the most relevant ways utilities are interdependent several possible mistakes people make whenever making statistical computations famous biases like the hot hand and fallacies overconfidence the belief that we are better than we really are with respect to ourselves and to others evidence showing that consumers have limited capacity to process information and firms know this well lectures readings class in this course students will analyze corporate law from an international and comparative perspective the seminars will cover number of both theoretical and practical aspects of corporate law using examples from the the and other jurisdictions reference will be made to the challenges that arise for both small and companies as well as multinational corporations especially in the aftermath of the current financial crisis in order to achieve this the course considers seminar and group discussions learning will be assessed through the seminar and an oral exam legal issues of importance in the area of international corporate governance and comparative corporate law the structure and application of corporate law in civil law and common law systems around the world the importance of corporate governance in the globalized business society and the interlinked financial markets of the century the role of multinational corporations nowadays and their impact in both developed and developing economies the relevant legal terminology in english through different activities and legal scenarios law and common law law and corporate governance in the of globalisation objective primacy theory shareholder value theory companies act of directors and management of the company of and chairman of the board of directors directors remuneration and incentives in corporate boards shareholders scandals and corporate governance regulation scandals in the europe and around the world crisis social responsibility and sustainabilty law and practice at international level and business ethics and the aim of the course is to learn and analyze the impact and causes of corporate scandals as well as the impact of capitalism and the rule of law on economic outcomes analyze corporate scandals in common law and civil law jurisdictions determine the impact of corporate sandals over legal systems and economic settings study common denominators if any of corporate scandals in different countries theory behind corporate scandals case studies depression enron worldcom madoff and ponzi schemes lysine case subprime mannesmann liverdoor bid in japan the case of south korea china aviation oil natural resources in russia refco bear sterns northern rock chispas inverlink polar enersis discussing cases of corporate scandals through reseach underatken by students every week reseach and verbal skills are developed with final presentation reading for participation in class oral presentation milhaupt curtis and pistor katharina what corporate crises reveal about legal and economic development around the world chicago university press

the course is aimed to analyze through case studies the general principles and exceptions that govern international trade in the context of the world trade organization in addition we shall review current issues affecting international relations and the economy to comprehend the importance of international trade and the different international organizations who participate in this area to analyze the historical context and the evolution of the within the context of the divide to understand the fundamental principal of global trade and international relations to show greater understanding of political social and economic issues that have dominated the news in the past several years introduction to international trade and economics and the role of the case for open trade introduction to the and the different aspects of the international organization principles and exceptions that govern global trade through the analysis of the general agreement on trade and tariffs most favored nation and tariffs national treatment exceptions economy and current issues study current political social and economic issues analysis of current cases that from political social and electoral view have an impact to the issues detailed in and above lectures from the professors analysis and debates of jurisprudence class participation through debates analysis of cases final exam dennin ferry law and practice of the world trade organization new york oceana jean monet center for international and reginal economy law justice school of law the law of the world trade organization through the cases http legal affairs division of the secretariat analytical index guide to law and practice ed cambridge cambridge university press junio
